articles.headline: A Taste of Hope in Somalia’s Battered Capital
articles.snippet: After 21 years of civil war, Mogadishu is making a remarkable comeback.
articles.abstract: After 21 years of civil war, Mogadishu is making a remarkable comeback.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Up until a few weeks ago, all visitors who landed at Aden Abdulle International Airport in Mogadishu were handed a poorly copied, barely readable sheet that asked for name, address — and caliber of weapon.

articles.headline: Wen Calls China Banks Too Powerful
articles.snippet: The unusually bold remarks by Prime Minister Wen Jiabao appeared to be a challenge to others in the Communist Party leadership to speed up reforms of the financial system.
articles.abstract: The unusually bold remarks by Prime Minister Wen Jiabao appeared to be a challenge to others in the Communist Party leadership to speed up reforms of the financial system.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China said on Tuesday that the nation’s biggest state-run banks have too much power and ought to be broken up because they earn far too much money.

articles.headline: Taking 3 States, Romney Looks Beyond G.O.P. Foes to Obama
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney tightened his grip on the Republican nomination on Tuesday, and found himself in his first direct engagement with President Obama.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney tightened his grip on the Republican nomination on Tuesday, and found himself in his first direct engagement with President Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Mitt Romney tightened his grip on the Republican nomination on Tuesday with a sweep of the primaries in Wisconsin, Maryland and the District of Columbia, and found himself in his first direct engagement with President Obama, an unmistakable signal that the general election would not wait for internal Republican politics.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Seeking U.S. Loans for Plant, Fisker Scrambles to Restore Credibility
articles.snippet: In search of a federal loan to build its cars at a plant in Delaware, Fisker is trying to re-establish its credibility as an independent automaker with cutting-edge technology.
articles.abstract: In search of a federal loan to build its cars at a plant in Delaware, Fisker is trying to re-establish its credibility as an independent automaker with cutting-edge technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Fisker Automotive’s huge assembly plant in Delaware stands vacant, waiting for the money, equipment and workers to make a new plug-in hybrid electric car backed by loans from the federal government.

articles.headline: Greece Is in a Face-Off With Its Bond Holdouts
articles.snippet: A few investors who will not agree to take losses on their bonds expect Athens and its supporters to pay them back rather than go into default, a move that analysts said could set a dangerous precedent.
articles.abstract: A few investors who will not agree to take losses on their bonds expect Athens and its supporters to pay them back rather than go into default, a move that analysts said could set a dangerous precedent.
articles.lead_paragraph: The battle between Greece and the vulture investors is about to begin.

articles.headline: The Promise of Today’s Factory Jobs
articles.snippet: Rewarding manufacturers who increase their payroll in the United States may not be as effective as supporting the firms whose creations can conquer world markets — and pay for the jobs of the rest of us.
articles.abstract: Rewarding manufacturers who increase their payroll in the United States may not be as effective as supporting the firms whose creations can conquer world markets — and pay for the jobs of the rest of us.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear Mike Bink, one might believe American manufacturing is about to recapture its lost glory.

articles.headline: In China Press, Best Coverage Cash Can Buy
articles.snippet: Though banned in China, paying for positive news coverage is so widespread that many publications and broadcasters have rate cards listing prices.
articles.abstract: Though banned in China, paying for positive news coverage is so widespread that many publications and broadcasters have rate cards listing prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — China is notorious for censoring politically delicate news coverage. But it is more than willing to let flattering news about Western and Asian businesses appear in print and broadcast media — if the price is right.

articles.headline: 2 Underdogs Produce, but in Time?
articles.snippet: Nokia and Microsoft joined forces to make the Lumia 900 a top-of-the-line device. But that doesn’t necessarily mean that people will flock to it.
articles.abstract: Nokia and Microsoft joined forces to make the Lumia 900 a top-of-the-line device. But that doesn’t necessarily mean that people will flock to it.
articles.lead_paragraph: What’s better than a good story about an underdog? A story about two of them.

articles.headline: Shares Dip as Fed Aims to Pull Back
articles.snippet: Wall Street stocks closed down about 1 percent, as investors digested the suggestion that further monetary stimulus action from the Fed was unlikely.
articles.abstract: Wall Street stocks closed down about 1 percent, as investors digested the suggestion that further monetary stimulus action from the Fed was unlikely.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors are looking toward the day when the Federal Reserve eases its bond purchases intended to support the economy, and so far they do not like what they see.
